posts.name: Owen
posts.cooked: Our team is having problems creating square corners for our bots frame with brackets, and cannot weld it for the next week or two. Due to that, and a need to finish our drive base as soon as possible (we are using an X drive, and need it done so programming can work with it more), we came up with the idea of using carbon fiber PLA (15% carbon fiber by weight, printed with an Ender K1), to make the corners and bearing supports. Are there any concerns or limitations we should know about? We plan on using this for the test base and will make it out of a better material for the competition bot.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
For prototyping?

Go for it.

How long will they be useful after the time it takes to print and install them? a week? 2 weeks? (Is the print time/cost worth it to you? keep in mind I do not know how large these prints are.)

posts.name: Corbin Kuster
posts.cooked: The way my team approaches welding is simple: Can it be repaired at competition? For us, no. Therefore we will never weld anything on a robot, or even a robot cart. I have never understood the hype around CF filaments. The only thing CF gains you is tensile strength, and I don’t think that means anything when the application is an angled bracket. If you were printing plates instead of brackets, maybe… but I still don’t think printing is the right answer. As Skyehawk said, it would absolutely be fine for a prototype. But I would never take a drivetrain to competition held together by 3DP components

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
CKioxide:

The only thing CF gains you is tensile strength, and I don’t think that means anything when the application is an angled bracket

Chopped and continuous CF can do weird and wonderful things when part of a printed part that are not immediately obvious.

posts.name: Owen
posts.cooked: Our team has slightly debated using the bumper as the main shock absorbing system, and if we had a sturdy enough/absorbant enough bumper we would look into using brakets at a high infill %. And the brackets would fit roughly 3 inches of the box tubing inside, and have .2in walls around it.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Voidbringer101:

Our team has slightly debated using the bumper as the main shock absorbing system,

Can you elaborate more? Maybe include a rough sketch or picture?

This sounds less like a bracket and more like a corner tube plug.

posts.name: Owen
posts.cooked: It fits the tubing inside and would use bolts to hold it in place. Its a 5.2x5.2x2.4 build volume, but can be changed

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Put a large radius filet in that brace corner (marked up in blue)

Beyond that, if it buys you a few days for programming go for it.
